is the capital of eponymous Ben Tre Province in
. Although only a 20 min ferry-ride away from bustling

, this seems to be barrier enough to give the town a genuine backwater feeling. Tourists are still a scarce species and locals are open and friendly.

Ben Tre Province provides some of the most beautiful scenery in the Mekong delta. The milk coffee coloured waters wind their way along small channels lined with water palms, thatch, and bamboo houses are nestled in the lush orchards. The famous Vietnamese poet Nguyen Dinh Chieu was born in Ben Tre Province.

(20 min/24 hr) arrive some 10 km north of Ben Tre, so you might want to hire a xe om to take you to the town centre.

There is a ferry from Vinh Long Province to the northwestern part of the island. Again you may want to hire some sort of transport to cover the remaining distance to Ben Tre town. There is also Bus 8 from the ferry pier to Ben Tre. It seems frequent, costs about 25,000 dong for 2h trip. You will need a taxi (moto ~ 20,000 dong for 10 min ride). Pay attention when arriving in Ben Tre as the bus goes to the outer bus station. Best is to stop at the roundabout after the two big bridges and Mat Kinh Dien Bien Phu optic shop and take a motorbike taxi (20,000 dong) to the town centre.
bus station. A bridge connects the city to

so the bus ride is direct, without a ferry. On arrival at the bus station in Ben Tre, a very welcoming man with good English will try to get you to his guesthouse by showing books and stuff. In fact, the ride there takes you back where your bus came from, halfway to My Tho, about 10 km from Ben Tre. Make sure to get from the Ben Tre bus station into the town of Ben Tre, not elsewhere.
The town stretches along the river, so a bicycle or a motorbike are the best way to get around.
There are no real sights in their own right, but you could have a look at the unspoiled
on the south bank, 0.5 km west of the old bridge. You can also visit the inevitable
here. It's a must if you haven't been to one yet, since in this "factory" basically everything is done by hand.

Trung Tam Dieu / Ben Tre tour operation centre (closed during lunch) has some tours by boat (US$ 25-30 for 1-2 persons,  3-4hr), by bike or cart and homestay addresses. It also gives information on the city.
Another option is to speak to one of the men standing around the tourist-oriented boat, which is in the area west of the new bridge. Some offer nice boat tours combined with biking on one of the islands for around US$30.

value: content=There are apparently four factories across town. The shop selling the coconut candy (keo dua) is in the front and the factory is in the back. The visit of the factory where you see the women making the handmade candy is free (there is a second shop across the street).

content=Boat trips are one of the nicest ways to negotiate the network of channels, but the land in between the waters is just as fascinating. It's fun to follow some of the small trails along the channels, crossing streams on very basic bridges and walking past fruit and coconut orchards.

There is a Coop Mart (food, department store, game centre) near Cong Vien Dong Khoi Park, north of the lake.
are found around the market. Be warned that one of the favourite soups in the delta,
, contains boiled intestines and liver. There is also a
near the old bridge. Sweet bakery for breakfast? Go to the huge Coop Mart (8-22) just behind street Hai Ba Trung.

value: content= Big seafood restaurant right at the beginning of town. Very popular with Vietnamese office workers and families.

Coldest beer in Ben Tre? Go to the Oasis.

value: content=One of the best hotels in Ben Tre with outside swimming pool, steam bath and sauna. Buffet breakfast is a mix of Asian and Western food. All rooms have Internet, TV with English channels.
price=150-240,000 dong. Strangely prices dropped if check-in after 16:00
content=Hot water except in cheapest rooms. Free Wi-Fi, restaurant, karaoke, massage.
directions=Town centre, north of Ho Truc Giang  Lake
content=Cold shower. Fan or air-con. Free Wi-Fi. Limited English-speaking staff.
directions=Town centre, street south of lake
content=Air-con, no Wi-Fi, limited English-speaking staff.
content=Kiwi and Vietnamese owners. Free Wi-Fi, swimming-pool, English, Viet, Khmer spoken. Cold beer, local knowledge.
directions=Red house in front of the town's lake.
content= Good service, limited English and friendly. All rooms with hot shower and fresh towel.

Either go to the outer bus station or get a minibus to My Tho or Ho Chi Minh City inside town.

value: : 70,000 dong, on Tran Quoc Tuan St north of the lake.
: ~20,000 dong, on Dong Khoi St, bus stop near school

Cargo boats also will take you to places like Tra Vinh, Can Tho, or Vinh Long. The boats leave between 08:30 and 09:00 every day. It takes a long time, but it's an adventurous and cheap option (expect to pay between 60,000-120,000 dong per person). They leave from the area east of the new bridge. Boats are light blue.
